title: 107_hr2645
content: The "Motor Donor Act" is the short title of the Act. It amends the Public Health Service Act to include a National Organ Donor Registry. The Motor Donor Act aims to increase organ and tissue donor registrations, improve information on donation, ensure accurate information on individuals' wishes, and provide grants to states for donor registries through driver's license applications. The Act defines a motor vehicle driver's license as any ID issued by a state motor vehicle authority. The Motor Donor Act establishes a national organ and tissue donor registry, including a database with individuals' information and a unique identification number. The Secretary will coordinate with states and organ procurement organizations during an initial 2-year period after the Act's enactment. During the initial 2-year period after the Motor Donor Act's enactment, the Secretary will coordinate with states to share data from existing organ and tissue donor registries and establish links with state agencies. Additionally, during the 4-year period, activities will be coordinated to promote the creation of registries through the driver's license process. The Secretary will also provide means for organ procurement organizations to access information promptly. The Motor Donor Act aims to provide organ procurement organizations in the United States with 24-hour access to the Registry using a designated password. The Secretary will disseminate information about organ and tissue donations to citizens through a pamphlet and website, allowing individuals to elect to participate in the Registry. The Motor Donor Act allows individuals to participate in the Registry through the website, with the Secretary notifying them of their participation. Participation does not affect organ allocation and is only considered an intent to donate. Individuals can cancel their participation at any time. The Motor Donor Act allows individuals to participate in the Registry through the website, with the Secretary notifying them of their right to cancel participation. Grants are available for States to implement State registries linked to the motor vehicle driver's license application process. States must submit applications demonstrating their procedures to receive grants. Each state must establish procedures for individuals to make legally binding organ and tissue donation gifts when applying for a driver's license. The procedures must comply with specific requirements outlined in the Motor Donor Act. The Motor Donor Act requires states to establish procedures for individuals to designate their intent to be an organ and tissue donor when applying for a driver's license. Only those who answer affirmatively will have their preference noted in the State registry. The Motor Donor Act mandates states to establish procedures for individuals to indicate their organ donor preference on their driver's license or State registry. Information of those who opt-in must be forwarded to the registry within 100 days, including any updates to their designation or address. Individuals who choose not to be organ donors will not have their name included in the State registry. The Motor Donor Act requires states to establish procedures for individuals to indicate their organ donor preference on their driver's license or State registry. Information of those who opt-in must be forwarded to the registry within 100 days. Individuals who choose not to be organ donors will not have their name included in the State registry. The State agency must provide 24-hour access to donor information to organ procurement organizations without any fees. The Motor Donor Act mandates states to establish procedures for organ donor preferences on driver's licenses or State registries. States must forward opt-in information to the registry within 100 days. Individuals opting out will not be included in the registry. State agencies must provide free 24-hour access to donor information for organ procurement organizations. The Secretary will prioritize grant awards to states collaborating with organ procurement organizations. Grants awarded to a single state under this subsection cannot exceed $300,000. An advisory task force on organ and tissue donation, consisting of 5 members appointed by the Secretary, has been established. Members are selected based on their experience with organ donation. The Task Force members are appointed based on their experience with organ donations, transplants, or procurement. At least one member must be a physician with transplant experience, and another must have organ procurement experience. Each member serves a 3-year term, with staggered terms for initial members. The Task Force members are appointed based on their experience with organ donations, transplants, or procurement. Terms of two initial members expire after 2 years. Vacancies do not affect powers but are filled in the same manner. The Task Force partners with the Coalition on Donation for a national awareness campaign. A report with recommendations for improving the Registry is due within 1 year of the Motor Donor Act enactment. The Task Force members do not receive compensation but are allowed travel expenses. The Secretary may accept voluntary services from Task Force members. The Secretary may accept voluntary and uncompensated services of Task Force members. Federal Government employees can be detailed to the Task Force without reimbursement. The Department of Health and Human Services will provide administrative support. The Task Force is exempt from the Federal Advisory Committee Act. Authorization of appropriations is provided for fiscal years 2002 through 2006. Authorization of appropriations is provided for fiscal years 2002 through 2006 for an awareness campaign, with $3,000,000 allocated annually for subsection (h)(3). Any appropriated amounts shall remain available until expended. SEC. 3. AMENDMENT OF INTERNAL REVENUE CODE. Section 6103(m) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to allow disclosure of taxpayer identification information to the Department of Health and Human Services for the purpose of contacting individuals regarding the national organ and tissue donor registry. SEC. 4. CONFORMING AMENDMENTS. Subpart 2 of part H of title III of the Public Health Service Act is amended in sections 374(a), 374(d), 375(1), and 378, by replacing "this part" with "this subpart".
